values.description:
This allows for shadows when using stereo rendering. It uses stencil shadows, which is CPU based instead of GPU based.

This is also running on beefy.

[Tutorial update](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/198).

[Jenkins pending](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-coverage-trusty-amd64/388)

values.description: When using the `USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS=False` cmake argument, we are invalidating all our recommended flags, which is fine except for those mandatory to work properly, like c++11.
values.title: Make C++11 flag unconditional (gazebo5 branch)

summary.raw: When using the `USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS=False` cmake argument, we are invalidating all our recommended flags, which is fine except for those mandatory to work properly, like c++11.
summary.html: When using the USE_UPSTREAM_CFLAGS=False cmake argument, we are invalidating all our recommended flags, which is fine except for those mandatory to work properly, like c++11.

values.description:
Fixed a number of issues with the first [PresetManager pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1471/presetmanager-for-physics-library/diff):

* Command line interface integrated. Use `gazebo <--profile|-o> <preset name>` to load your chosen preset at the start. Note that this won't unless you also specify a world file with the physics profile you are trying to load.
* You can also do `gz physics <--profile|-p> <preset name>` to set the profile during real-time.
* Added a "name" field to `physics.proto` message. This might be subject to change with future changes to the physics protobuf message structure.
* SDF generation implemented (see `GenerateSDFFromPreset`)
* Unit `PresetManager_TEST` added for more coverage.
* Added `bool PresetManager::HasProfile(string name)` to check if the PresetManager has a profile.
* Check before adding parameters under a different physics engine block than the actual physics engine type (e.g. won't add Simbody parameters to an ODE block). This gets rid of a lot of warnings.
* various bug and style fixes

Putting this at a high priority because it's DRCSim milestone-related.

[Tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/201/preset-manager-tutorial/diff) is in a pull request.
values.title: PresetManager Part 2: command line, SDF generation, unit test

summary.raw:
Fixed a number of issues with the first [PresetManager pull request](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1471/presetmanager-for-physics-library/diff):

* Command line interface integrated. Use `gazebo <--profile|-o> <preset name>` to load your chosen preset at the start. Note that this won't unless you also specify a world file with the physics profile you are trying to load.
* You can also do `gz physics <--profile|-p> <preset name>` to set the profile during real-time.
* Added a "name" field to `physics.proto` message. This might be subject to change with future changes to the physics protobuf message structure.
* SDF generation implemented (see `GenerateSDFFromPreset`)
* Unit `PresetManager_TEST` added for more coverage.
* Added `bool PresetManager::HasProfile(string name)` to check if the PresetManager has a profile.
* Check before adding parameters under a different physics engine block than the actual physics engine type (e.g. won't add Simbody parameters to an ODE block). This gets rid of a lot of warnings.
* various bug and style fixes

Putting this at a high priority because it's DRCSim milestone-related.

[Tutorial](#!/osrf/gazebo_tutorials/pull-request/201/preset-manager-tutorial/diff) is in a pull request.
summary.html:
Fixed a number of issues with the first PresetManager pull request:

  • Command line interface integrated. Use gazebo <--profile|-o> <preset name> to load your chosen preset at the start. Note that this won't unless you also specify a world file with the physics profile you are trying to load.
  • You can also do gz physics <--profile|-p> <preset name> to set the profile during real-time.
  • Added a "name" field to physics.proto message. This might be subject to change with future changes to the physics protobuf message structure.
  • SDF generation implemented (see GenerateSDFFromPreset)
  • Unit PresetManager_TEST added for more coverage.
  • Added bool PresetManager::HasProfile(string name) to check if the PresetManager has a profile.
  • Check before adding parameters under a different physics engine block than the actual physics engine type (e.g. won't add Simbody parameters to an ODE block). This gets rid of a lot of warnings.
  • various bug and style fixes

Putting this at a high priority because it's DRCSim milestone-related.

Tutorial is in a pull request.

summary.html: naming confusion, some references to PGS (Projected Gauss-Seidel) should have stayed as SOR (Successive Over-Relaxation).

values.description:
More failures in `MainWindow_TEST` revealed some outlying bugs:

1. In `GLWidget`, `modelEditorEnabled` must be initialized to `false`, otherwise `MainWindow_TEST::CopyPaste` fails occasionally. The failures are because `GLWidget` thinks `modelEditorEnabled=true` and disables copy/pasting.

2. In `ModelSnap`, use `Visual::DeleteDynamicLines` instead of simply calling `delete` on the `DynamicLines` object, because this function both deletes the object and removes its pointer from `Visual`. The original deletion strategy was causing a segfault in `MainWindow_TEST::SceneDestruction`.

I also added some more calls to `processEvents` and consolidated `wait` calls in `MainWindow_TEST`. These might, however, be extraneous and I am happy to delete them with more testing.

@scpeters noticed frequent (~80%) test failures from overnight builds on default. I've run manual tests on this branch about 15 times and seen no segfaults, but perhaps we should run an overnight build on this before approving, just in case.
values.title: More MainWindow/GLWidget fixes

summary.raw:
More failures in `MainWindow_TEST` revealed some outlying bugs:

1. In `GLWidget`, `modelEditorEnabled` must be initialized to `false`, otherwise `MainWindow_TEST::CopyPaste` fails occasionally. The failures are because `GLWidget` thinks `modelEditorEnabled=true` and disables copy/pasting.

2. In `ModelSnap`, use `Visual::DeleteDynamicLines` instead of simply calling `delete` on the `DynamicLines` object, because this function both deletes the object and removes its pointer from `Visual`. The original deletion strategy was causing a segfault in `MainWindow_TEST::SceneDestruction`.

I also added some more calls to `processEvents` and consolidated `wait` calls in `MainWindow_TEST`. These might, however, be extraneous and I am happy to delete them with more testing.

@scpeters noticed frequent (~80%) test failures from overnight builds on default. I've run manual tests on this branch about 15 times and seen no segfaults, but perhaps we should run an overnight build on this before approving, just in case.
summary.html:
More failures in MainWindow_TEST revealed some outlying bugs:

  1. In GLWidget, modelEditorEnabled must be initialized to false, otherwise MainWindow_TEST::CopyPaste fails occasionally. The failures are because GLWidget thinks modelEditorEnabled=true and disables copy/pasting.

  2. In ModelSnap, use Visual::DeleteDynamicLines instead of simply calling delete on the DynamicLines object, because this function both deletes the object and removes its pointer from Visual. The original deletion strategy was causing a segfault in MainWindow_TEST::SceneDestruction.

I also added some more calls to processEvents and consolidated wait calls in MainWindow_TEST. These might, however, be extraneous and I am happy to delete them with more testing.

@scpeters noticed frequent (~80%) test failures from overnight builds on default. I've run manual tests on this branch about 15 times and seen no segfaults, but perhaps we should run an overnight build on this before approving, just in case.

values.description:
First part of schematic view (without icons)

* added `qgv` library (LGPL) located at `gazebo/gui/model/qgv` to help draw graphs in Qt.

* added optional dependency on libgraphviz-dev for doing graph layouts

To open the schematic view:

1. Go in model editor

1. From the menubar: Window -> Schematic View

To open the schematic view:

First part of schematic view (without icons)

  • added qgv library (LGPL) located at gazebo/gui/model/qgv to help draw graphs in Qt.

To open the schematic view:

values.description:
It was observed that users get confused about the save location and the model name. Talking to @spaepcke we thought it might help to take the model name out of Advanced Options and synchronize the fields on user input:

* Location updates when editing name

* But editing location doesn't change name

* Changing location with browse keeps the last folder name, which is synced with the model name
values.title: Sync name and location on SaveDialog

summary.raw:
It was observed that users get confused about the save location and the model name. Talking to @spaepcke we thought it might help to take the model name out of Advanced Options and synchronize the fields on user input:

* Location updates when editing name

* But editing location doesn't change name

* Changing location with browse keeps the last folder name, which is synced with the model name
summary.html:
It was observed that users get confused about the save location and the model name. Talking to @spaepcke we thought it might help to take the model name out of Advanced Options and synchronize the fields on user input:

  • Location updates when editing name

  • But editing location doesn't change name

  • Changing location with browse keeps the last folder name, which is synced with the model name

values.description:
Display different widgets for simulation time and for log playback.

Sorry for the large PR, I could separate into smaller ones, but I think these changes only make sense if done as a whole.

1. Added optional `log_playback` field to `world_stats.proto` to indicate whether it's playback or not.

1. Fill `log_playback` field when publishing message from `physics::World`.

1. `TimePanel` still subscribes to the message, but now it displays either `TimeWidget` or `LogPlayWidget` depending on the message.

1. All publishing and subscribing should be going through `TimePanel`, which now works more like a "time manager".

1. `TimeWidget` contains all the GUI elements which were in `TimePanel` before.

1. Display related tests from `TimePanel` were moved to `TimeWidget_TEST`.

1. `LogPlayWidget` for now is a simplified version of `TimeWidget` containing only the elements which currently make sense for log playback (removed real-time related stuff).

1. Didn't create tests for `LogPlayWidget` because it will be changed to the new template soon. I'll be modifying it as we implement what's needed in the back-end.

1. Moved `OnPlayActionChanged` from `MainWindow` to `TimePanel` because I think that makes more sense.

1. PIMPLized `TimePanel`.

![logplaywidget.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3930024772-logplaywidget.png)


* To see `TimeWidget`:

Start Gazebo normally.

* To see `LogPlayWidget`:

Record a log: Start Gazebo, insert something which moves, such as a double pendulum, then `Window -> Log Data` and use the record button. Note where the log file was saved.

Close Gazebo and then restart it to playback the file saved, something like `gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/...`
values.title: Separate TimePanel's display into TimeWidget and LogPlayWidget

Sorry for the large PR, I could separate into smaller ones, but I think these changes only make sense if done as a whole.

1. Added optional `log_playback` field to `world_stats.proto` to indicate whether it's playback or not.

1. Fill `log_playback` field when publishing message from `physics::World`.

1. `LogPlayWidget` for now is a simplified version of `TimeWidget` containing only the elements which currently make sense for log playback (removed real-time related stuff).

![logplaywidget.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3930024772-logplaywidget.png)

Close Gazebo and then restart it to playback the file saved, something like `gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/...`
summary.html:
Display different widgets for simulation time and for log playback.

Sorry for the large PR, I could separate into smaller ones, but I think these changes only make sense if done as a whole.

  1. Added optional log_playback field to world_stats.proto to indicate whether it's playback or not.

  2. Fill log_playback field when publishing message from physics::World.

  3. TimePanel still subscribes to the message, but now it displays either TimeWidget or LogPlayWidget depending on the message.

  4. All publishing and subscribing should be going through TimePanel, which now works more like a "time manager".

  5. TimeWidget contains all the GUI elements which were in TimePanel before.

  6. Display related tests from TimePanel were moved to TimeWidget_TEST.

  7. LogPlayWidget for now is a simplified version of TimeWidget containing only the elements which currently make sense for log playback (removed real-time related stuff).

  8. Didn't create tests for LogPlayWidget because it will be changed to the new template soon. I'll be modifying it as we implement what's needed in the back-end.

  9. Moved OnPlayActionChanged from MainWindow to TimePanel because I think that makes more sense.

  10. PIMPLized TimePanel.

  • To see TimeWidget:

Start Gazebo normally.

  • To see LogPlayWidget:

Record a log: Start Gazebo, insert something which moves, such as a double pendulum, then Window -> Log Data and use the record button. Note where the log file was saved.

Close Gazebo and then restart it to playback the file saved, something like gazebo -p ~/.gazebo/log/...

values.description:
Fix #124 and conform to REP 117, report +/-inf for ranges outside of ray sensor capability, instead of clipping at min/max range.

Replaces the ill-conceived PR #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1375/fix-124
values.title: Report +/-inf for ranges outside of ray sensor capability

summary.raw:
Fix #124 and conform to REP 117, report +/-inf for ranges outside of ray sensor capability, instead of clipping at min/max range.

Replaces the ill-conceived PR #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1375/fix-124
summary.html:
Fix #124 and conform to REP 117, report +/-inf for ranges outside of ray sensor capability, instead of clipping at min/max range.

Replaces the ill-conceived PR #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1375/fix-124

values.description:
`sdf::SDF::root` was deprecated in [sdformat pull request 158](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/158/windows-clean-build-part-2/diff). This increases the minimum required sdformat version to 3.0.2 and then converts to using the new API.

There was one set of warnings that I didn't now how to fix.
~~~
tools/gz.cc: In member function ‘virtual bool gazebo::SDFCommand::RunImpl()’:
tools/gz.cc:932:13: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
   sdf::SDF::version = SDF_VERSION;
             ^
tools/gz.cc:951:17: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
       sdf::SDF::version = boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(
                 ^
tools/gz.cc:1001:54: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
       if (sdf::Converter::Convert(&xmlDoc, sdf::SDF::version, true))
                                                      ^
~~~
`sdf::SDF::version` used to be a writable public static variable, but now there is just an accessor. I don't know why we are trying to write to it in `gz.cc`. @nkoenig can you comment?
values.title: Fix warnings when using sdformat 3.0.2 prerelease

summary.raw:
`sdf::SDF::root` was deprecated in [sdformat pull request 158](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/158/windows-clean-build-part-2/diff). This increases the minimum required sdformat version to 3.0.2 and then converts to using the new API.

There was one set of warnings that I didn't now how to fix.
~~~
tools/gz.cc: In member function ‘virtual bool gazebo::SDFCommand::RunImpl()’:
tools/gz.cc:932:13: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
   sdf::SDF::version = SDF_VERSION;
             ^
tools/gz.cc:951:17: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
       sdf::SDF::version = boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(
                 ^
tools/gz.cc:1001:54: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
       if (sdf::Converter::Convert(&xmlDoc, sdf::SDF::version, true))
                                                      ^
~~~
`sdf::SDF::version` used to be a writable public static variable, but now there is just an accessor. I don't know why we are trying to write to it in `gz.cc`. @nkoenig can you comment?
summary.html:
sdf::SDF::root was deprecated in sdformat pull request 158. This increases the minimum required sdformat version to 3.0.2 and then converts to using the new API.

There was one set of warnings that I didn't now how to fix.

tools/gz.cc: In member function ‘virtual bool gazebo::SDFCommand::RunImpl()’:
tools/gz.cc:932:13: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
   sdf::SDF::version = SDF_VERSION;
             ^
tools/gz.cc:951:17: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
       sdf::SDF::version = boost::lexical_cast<std::string>(
                 ^
tools/gz.cc:1001:54: warning: ‘sdf::SDF::version’ is deprecated (declared at /usr/include/sdformat-3.0/sdf/SDFImpl.hh:389) [-Wdeprecated-declarations]
       if (sdf::Converter::Convert(&xmlDoc, sdf::SDF::version, true))
                                                      ^

sdf::SDF::version used to be a writable public static variable, but now there is just an accessor. I don't know why we are trying to write to it in gz.cc. @nkoenig can you comment?

values.description:
**Note: Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo.**

You can plug two Hydra's and the plugin will start publishing updates on `~/hydra0`, `~/hydra1`, etc.

For testing:

* Follow [this tutorial](http://www.gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=hydra&cat=user_input).
* Plug in two Hydra's.
* Start gazebo with the `hydra_demo.world`. You should be able to control each sphere with the right joystick of each Hydra.
values.title: [DRC Expo: foosball] Support for multiple Hydra's

summary.raw:
**Note: Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo.**

You can plug two Hydra's and the plugin will start publishing updates on `~/hydra0`, `~/hydra1`, etc.

For testing:

* Follow [this tutorial](http://www.gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=hydra&cat=user_input).
* Plug in two Hydra's.
* Start gazebo with the `hydra_demo.world`. You should be able to control each sphere with the right joystick of each Hydra.
summary.html:
Note: Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo.

You can plug two Hydra's and the plugin will start publishing updates on ~/hydra0, ~/hydra1, etc.

For testing:

  • Follow this tutorial.
  • Plug in two Hydra's.
  • Start gazebo with the hydra_demo.world. You should be able to control each sphere with the right joystick of each Hydra.

values.description:
Use `GAZEBO_CFLAGS` (pkg-config) or `GAZEBO_CXX_FLAGS` (cmake find_package) in example plugin compilation CMakeLists.txt files (fixes a bunch of test failures).

This requires [sdformat pull request 172](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/172/add-std-c-11-flag-to-sdf_configcmakein-and/diff)

values.description:
** Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo **

* Allows multiple players to move the rods.
* Allows a player to switch the rod by pressing the trigger button.
* You can specify in the world file the rods assigned to the left/right controller.
* You can specify in the world file `<oculus>1</oculus>` and if you're in the read team, you're controllers will be adjusted.

~~Review pull request #1572 before this one.~~
values.title: [DRC Expo: Foosball] Model plugin that controls the rods.

summary.raw:
** Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo **

* Allows multiple players to move the rods.
* Allows a player to switch the rod by pressing the trigger button.
* You can specify in the world file the rods assigned to the left/right controller.
* You can specify in the world file `<oculus>1</oculus>` and if you're in the read team, you're controllers will be adjusted.

~~Review pull request #1572 before this one.~~
summary.html:
Ignore this pull request unless you're working on the foosball demo

  • Allows multiple players to move the rods.
  • Allows a player to switch the rod by pressing the trigger button.
  • You can specify in the world file the rods assigned to the left/right controller.
  • You can specify in the world file <oculus>1</oculus> and if you're in the read team, you're controllers will be adjusted.

Review pull request #1572 before this one.

values.description:
Made it possible to specify on the SDF if you want to display buttons:

~~~
        <start_stop_button>1</start_stop_button>
        <reset_button>1</reset_button>
~~~

Updated example world to display 3 different timers with and without buttons, subscribing to different topics:

![timerButtons.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/183583672-timerButtons.png)
values.title: Added optional start/stop/reset buttons to the timer GUI plugin

summary.raw:

values.description:
This patch creates two new member variables in the LogPlay class to keep track of the start and stop times of a log episode. Additionally, it will create two new accessors for exposing the log file name and file size. In the near future, log name, log size and start/stop time will be used by the GUI playback tool.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.

I'll submit a new pull request with some unit tests for this class.
values.title: Add the start/stop time to the log files

summary.raw:
This patch creates two new member variables in the LogPlay class to keep track of the start and stop times of a log episode. Additionally, it will create two new accessors for exposing the log file name and file size. In the near future, log name, log size and start/stop time will be used by the GUI playback tool.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with `gazebo -p <log file> --verbose` and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.

I'll submit a new pull request with some unit tests for this class.
summary.html:
This patch creates two new member variables in the LogPlay class to keep track of the start and stop times of a log episode. Additionally, it will create two new accessors for exposing the log file name and file size. In the near future, log name, log size and start/stop time will be used by the GUI playback tool.

For testing just create a log file as usual. Then, play the log file with gazebo -p <log file> --verbose and you should see the start/stop times printed on the screen.

I'll submit a new pull request with some unit tests for this class.

values.description:
Implementing the Apply Force/Torque GUI, I saw the need to get a link's CoM coordinates from the client side. My first implementation used request/response to ask the server for it, which is not ideal.

But in fact, the client holds this information in a few places, it was just difficult to access them. So this pull request adds a getter to `COMVisual` to easily access that information.
values.title: Add inertia pose getter for COMVisual, with test

summary.raw:
Implementing the Apply Force/Torque GUI, I saw the need to get a link's CoM coordinates from the client side. My first implementation used request/response to ask the server for it, which is not ideal.

But in fact, the client holds this information in a few places, it was just difficult to access them. So this pull request adds a getter to `COMVisual` to easily access that information.
summary.html:
Implementing the Apply Force/Torque GUI, I saw the need to get a link's CoM coordinates from the client side. My first implementation used request/response to ask the server for it, which is not ideal.

But in fact, the client holds this information in a few places, it was just difficult to access them. So this pull request adds a getter to COMVisual to easily access that information.

values.description:
* Added show toolbar action

* Moved `Fullscreen` and `Show GUI Overlays` together with the new action to the `Window` menu

* Added Reset actions to the main window so their shortcuts work on fullscreen. I didn't add all actions with shortcuts to the main window because there might be conflicts, for example, `Ctrl+S` is used in the simulation, in the building editor and in the model editor.
values.title: Added option to show or hide toolbars and rearranged menu

summary.raw:
* Added show toolbar action

* Moved `Fullscreen` and `Show GUI Overlays` together with the new action to the `Window` menu

* Added Reset actions to the main window so their shortcuts work on fullscreen. I didn't add all actions with shortcuts to the main window because there might be conflicts, for example, `Ctrl+S` is used in the simulation, in the building editor and in the model editor.
summary.html:
• Added show toolbar action

  • Moved Fullscreen and Show GUI Overlays together with the new action to the Window menu

  • Added Reset actions to the main window so their shortcuts work on fullscreen. I didn't add all actions with shortcuts to the main window because there might be conflicts, for example, Ctrl+S is used in the simulation, in the building editor and in the model editor.

values.description: While writing tests for the [Haptix Sim API implementation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/src/168c424fa569947b2d8283e321c4aa16546aaa48/test/integration/sim_api.cc), I ran into segfaults while accessing some `ODEJoint`. This PR fixes those segfaults by checking for a null `dJointFeedback` object for `ODEJoint`.
values.title: Small fixes for segfaults in Model, ODEJoint

summary.raw: While writing tests for the [Haptix Sim API implementation](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/src/168c424fa569947b2d8283e321c4aa16546aaa48/test/integration/sim_api.cc), I ran into segfaults while accessing some `ODEJoint`. This PR fixes those segfaults by checking for a null `dJointFeedback` object for `ODEJoint`.
summary.html: While writing tests for the Haptix Sim API implementation, I ran into segfaults while accessing some ODEJoint. This PR fixes those segfaults by checking for a null dJointFeedback object for ODEJoint.

values.description:
Change ServerFixture api for specifying system plugins, update rest-web.cc test accordingly, and disable failures in rest-web.cc

There were some test regressions caused by pull request #1524 that modified `ServerFixture::RunServer`. Previously, it was calling `Server::PreLoad`, but pull request #1524 replaced that call with a call to `Server::ParseArgs`. Our quick fix is to restore the `Server::PreLoad` call, and add a loop to call `gazebo::addPlugin` on a vector of strings corresponding to system plugins.

Hugo and I updated the rest_web.cc test with the new API, but it's currently failing. So we commented out the offending lines for now, so default can be fixed. Hugo will fix the test in a separate intervention.

We will wait for Jenkins confirmation before merging.
values.title: Fix bunch of failing tests on default

summary.raw:
Change ServerFixture api for specifying system plugins, update rest-web.cc test accordingly, and disable failures in rest-web.cc

There were some test regressions caused by pull request #1524 that modified `ServerFixture::RunServer`. Previously, it was calling `Server::PreLoad`, but pull request #1524 replaced that call with a call to `Server::ParseArgs`. Our quick fix is to restore the `Server::PreLoad` call, and add a loop to call `gazebo::addPlugin` on a vector of strings corresponding to system plugins.

Hugo and I updated the rest_web.cc test with the new API, but it's currently failing. So we commented out the offending lines for now, so default can be fixed. Hugo will fix the test in a separate intervention.

We will wait for Jenkins confirmation before merging.
summary.html:
Change ServerFixture api for specifying system plugins, update rest-web.cc test accordingly, and disable failures in rest-web.cc

There were some test regressions caused by pull request #1524 that modified ServerFixture::RunServer. Previously, it was calling Server::PreLoad, but pull request #1524 replaced that call with a call to Server::ParseArgs. Our quick fix is to restore the Server::PreLoad call, and add a loop to call gazebo::addPlugin on a vector of strings corresponding to system plugins.

Hugo and I updated the rest_web.cc test with the new API, but it's currently failing. So we commented out the offending lines for now, so default can be fixed. Hugo will fix the test in a separate intervention.

We will wait for Jenkins confirmation before merging.

values.description:
I just started getting compiler warnings on OS X Yosemite about the use of a floating point constant `1e9` used in integer calculations in  `common::Time::Correct`:
~~~
gazebo/common/Time.hh:434:32: warning: using integer absolute value function 'abs'
      when argument is of floating point type [-Wabsolute-value]
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^
gazebo/common/Time.hh:434:32: note: use function 'std::abs' instead
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^~~
                               std::abs
gazebo/common/Time.hh:440:32: warning: using integer absolute value function 'abs'
      when argument is of floating point type [-Wabsolute-value]
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^
gazebo/common/Time.hh:440:32: note: use function 'std::abs' instead
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^~~
                               std::abs
~~~
It recommends a floating point absolute value function, but I think it's more efficient and precise to use an integer constant instead of a floating point constant, since the end result is an integer anyway.

This is a fix targeted at `gazebo_4.1`. For c++11 (gazebo5+), some people [recommend user-defined literals](http://stackoverflow.com/a/24389792), but I'm happy with this implementation for now.

UPDATE: I found a few more warnings to fix and I added them to this pull request:

* 5099ef0: Use `std::abs(double)` instead of `abs(int)` in WirelessTransmitter.cc
~~~
gazebo/sensors/WirelessTransmitter.cc:180:14: warning: using integer absolute value
      function 'abs' when argument is of floating point type [-Wabsolute-value]
  double x = abs(math::Rand::GetDblNormal(0.0, ModelStdDesv));
             ^
gazebo/sensors/WirelessTransmitter.cc:180:14: note: use function 'std::abs' instead
  double x = abs(math::Rand::GetDblNormal(0.0, ModelStdDesv));
             ^~~
             std::abs
1 warning generated.
~~~
* 9f6a109: Don't use `this` when subscribing with a non-member callback function in MainWindow_TEST.cc. Use latching = `true` to preserve existing functionality.
~~~
gazebo/gui/MainWindow_TEST.cc:408:50: warning: 'this' pointer cannot be null in
      well-defined C++ code; pointer may be assumed to always convert to true [-Wundefined-bool-conversion]
  sub = node->Subscribe("~/request", &OnRequest, this);
        ~~~~                                     ^~~~
~~~

The following wasn't from a compiler warning, but I was reading about how you're not supposed to throw exceptions from a destructor, and noticed this and decided to fix it.
* 496fee3: Add try/catch around pubsync and close functions (both of which can throw) in `~Buffer` to ensure no exceptions are thrown from the destructor
values.title: Fix several clang compiler warnings

This is a fix targeted at `gazebo_4.1`. For c++11 (gazebo5+), some people [recommend user-defined literals](http://stackoverflow.com/a/24389792), but I'm happy with this implementation for now.

* 496fee3: Add try/catch around pubsync and close functions (both of which can throw) in `~Buffer` to ensure no exceptions are thrown from the destructor

gazebo/common/Time.hh:434:32: warning: using integer absolute value function 'abs'
      when argument is of floating point type [-Wabsolute-value]
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^
gazebo/common/Time.hh:434:32: note: use function 'std::abs' instead
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^~~
                               std::abs
gazebo/common/Time.hh:440:32: warning: using integer absolute value function 'abs'
      when argument is of floating point type [-Wabsolute-value]
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^
gazebo/common/Time.hh:440:32: note: use function 'std::abs' instead
                   int32_t n = abs(this->nsec / 1e9) + 1;
                               ^~~
                               std::abs

It recommends a floating point absolute value function, but I think it's more efficient and precise to use an integer constant instead of a floating point constant, since the end result is an integer anyway.

This is a fix targeted at gazebo_4.1. For c++11 (gazebo5+), some people recommend user-defined literals, but I'm happy with this implementation for now.

UPDATE: I found a few more warnings to fix and I added them to this pull request:

  • 5099ef0: Use std::abs(double) instead of abs(int) in WirelessTransmitter.cc
gazebo/sensors/WirelessTransmitter.cc:180:14: warning: using integer absolute value
      function 'abs' when argument is of floating point type [-Wabsolute-value]
  double x = abs(math::Rand::GetDblNormal(0.0, ModelStdDesv));
             ^
gazebo/sensors/WirelessTransmitter.cc:180:14: note: use function 'std::abs' instead

      well-defined C++ code; pointer may be assumed to always convert to true [-Wundefined-bool-conversion]

The following wasn't from a compiler warning, but I was reading about how you're not supposed to throw exceptions from a destructor, and noticed this and decided to fix it. * 496fee3: Add try/catch around pubsync and close functions (both of which can throw) in ~Buffer to ensure no exceptions are thrown from the destructor

values.description:
This shouldn't change the current behavior of the align tool, both during simulation or in the model editor.

This pull request moves the highlighting logic to a separate function which can be called recursively, unlike the currently logic which only goes one level deep.  This is in preparation for supporting nested models.
values.title: Highlight visuals on align independently of how nested they are, with test

summary.raw:
This shouldn't change the current behavior of the align tool, both during simulation or in the model editor.

This pull request moves the highlighting logic to a separate function which can be called recursively, unlike the currently logic which only goes one level deep.  This is in preparation for supporting nested models.
summary.html:
This shouldn't change the current behavior of the align tool, both during simulation or in the model editor.

This pull request moves the highlighting logic to a separate function which can be called recursively, unlike the currently logic which only goes one level deep. This is in preparation for supporting nested models.
